 I saw a story about the Mormon Church* established in Northern Ireland - a good place for a religious debate. They had vast stores of food, clothing etc, which they gave out to the needy - Mormons.
 
 In pagan times rich Romans would build public temples, etc, because it increased their stature amongst the locals. It was a kind of way of saying "See, I've got so much money, I can throw it away on an outrageous project".
 
 As I argued with Mizmaxx on the Islam posts there is no Islamic equal to the phrase "Turn the other cheek"
 The closest she found was "If your enemy wants peace, be peaceful"
 
 One could argue that this is Islam being a religion of peace - but the difference are immense.
 Christ is saying "Be peaceful, regardless"
 Muhammed is saying "Be peaceful, if you can find an opportune moment"
 
 I see Buddhist monks, getting charity from other Buddhists... begging for, and receiving food.
 
 Mother Theressa helped those who needed help - without checking to see if they were Catholic first.
 
 
 *I don't regard them as being "Christian". They believe in Christ, but so do many other non-Christian faiths, such as Ba'hai.

 First of all, as for the example you used with buddhsit monks setting out their begging bowl, and your assumption that only buddhists make offerings to them, that is flatly wrong. It is very common practice for a monk (or laymen) to beg, either for food, or other materials such as clothing, bedding, medications... The generous spirit of those who are in societies where they commonly encounter such actions bring them to charitous acts of kindness. A japanese monk rarely goes hungry, although a very large percentage of the citizens have turned away from their religious roots (just like America) 
 The same goes the other way around... a buddhist temple often commits a large share of it's funding to charitous works outside the temple in the surrounding community. They give aid to anyone in need, not just the buddhists. 
 The practice of begging food stems directly from the buddha's own actions, himself coming to death because he ate rotten meat that was placed in his bowl. why he did that is a question for another time.
 
 And while mahayana buddhists strive to "save all sentient beings" you will not find a buddhist missionary easily, while christian ones are quite common. Mother Theresa and others of her ilk have done wonderful acts of kindness, but all the while they have been trying to woo people into their religion. I wonder if perhaps an act of kindness is even better if there is no ulterior motive, such as getting into heaven.

what exactly do you mean by "meaningless sh*t" and who exactly do you think is being forced into it?

 Not quite what she did.
 
 There were untochables who spent their whole lives in actual filth. They had mostly miserable existences and when it came time to die, had a lonely death in the gutter.
 
 Mother T took them in and cleaned them up and stayed with them. She did pray for them, but she didn't expect them to have death-bed conversions. Her mission was to make their end half-way decent. To at least let them feel human for some time in their lives.
 
 For sure, her actions would have no doubt influenced those that saw death as being a long way off - and who had time to decide whether to convert or not.
 
 But regardless of whether they converted on their death beds, she still looked after them - that was it, the point. To do good for them, regardless of their religious beliefs - even if they hated her for it.
